file_content.text: I understand Senator Barc got the chips back. I may not be able to prosecute you, but I'll watching.
You did the right thing, turning in those control chips.
Look what the wampa dragged in. I was beginning to wonder if I'd see you again.
Did you get the shipment of slave collar chips?
Take these chips and destroy them, Captain.
They're all yours.
Oh, I will. Senator Barc'll be disappointed, but the law is the law... even for Senators.
I know he probably offered more, but I can at least give you the standard rate for your work.
I'm just glad we found them before Senator Barc did.
Happy to help.
I'm with you on that. To be honest, I can't think of a more detestable technology.
I appreciate it.
You're welcome. You've earned those credits.
I want more than "standard."
I'd like to help, but Security Personnel Regulation A-76 only authorizes so much for an operation like this one.
I've got a lot of datawork to do now. We don't want the Senator finding any fault with the way this was handled--but you've got my thanks.
I'm afraid I don't have anything for you, Captain.
No.
Well, get the chips as soon as you can. We don't want the guild to sell them out from under us.
Get into the guild warehouse and find the chips. Bring them to me and I'll destroy the whole shipment.
In accordance with Security Force Regulation 11-95, conversations with non-security personnel are to be kept to a minimum. Let's make this quick.
I'm Captain Denal-zon. Senator Barc's page "ordered" me to give you information regarding the Senator's stolen goods.
Where can I find the shipment?
Tell me what you know.
Look, I don't work for him. If you want that information, we're gonna have to come to an understanding.
I wouldn't let him order me around.
You shouldn't put up with it.
Good. That's why we need to reach an understanding here.
So follow orders.
We'll see. Under Security Appropriations Policy B-71, I am allowed to share classified information--if you're working for us.
Did the Senator's crony tell you where the shipment came from, or what these computer chips are for?
Now that you mention it, he didn't explain anything about the chips.
I wasn't told much.
I'm not surprised. These political types like to gloss over details.
Out with it--what are the chips for?
Just talk.
I'm not paid to ask questions.
All right, I get it. You should still know the truth, though.
The chips are from the planet Ryloth. They're designed to operate remote control slave collars.
Under Republic Law 44-12, Rylothian slave collars and the chips used to make them are illegal in Republic space--even for Senators.
Why would a Senator need chips for slave collars?
I don't understand.
To be honest, I don't know--but it really doesn't change anything. The law is the law.
Barc must be aware of the laws.
The Senator isn't ignorant....
Sure. He just doesn't think they apply to him.
Slavery is an abomination to the Force.
This is shameful.
The fact is, possession of those chips is against the law.
The Republic has bigger problems than illegal chips.
This isn't a critical issue.
True, but the law is the law, and the Senator is not above that.
Those chips must be worth a pile of credits.
So they're hard to get, huh?
The Migrant Merchants' Guild wouldn't have stolen them otherwise.
Not my problem.
Put on one of those slave collars and let me shock you a few times. You'll care.
Our immediate problem is that these slave collar chips are spread around the Migrant Merchants' Guild headquarters.
First priority is get the shipment together again. After that, bring the chips back to me and I'll make sure they're destroyed.
That sounds like the right thing to do.
Agreed.
It's the only thing to do.
Do you intend to prosecute Senator Barc for this?
What about the Senator?
Not up to me. My superiors will decide how to proceed with the case.
Are you offering a reward?
I can offer you the standard rate. The Senator's probably offering more, but it'll be dirty money.
Find the chips and get out of the guild warehouse. Once you've got everything, I suggest you let us deal with the shipment--not the Senator.
Move along. Security Regulation 44-13 designates security barricades as no-loitering zones.
